title: Chautauqua County-Jamestown Airport
text:
Chautauqua County/Jamestown Airport at <a href="Robert%20H.%20Jackson">Robert H. Jackson</a> Field is a county-owned, public-use <a href="airport">airport</a> located three <a href="nautical%20mile">nautical mile</a>s (6 <a href="kilometre">km</a>) north of the <a href="central%20business%20district">central business district</a> of <a href="Jamestown%2C%20New%20York">Jamestown</a>, in <a href="Chautauqua%20County%2C%20New%20York">Chautauqua County</a>, <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. It is mostly used for <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a>.
As per the <a href="Federal%20Aviation%20Administration">Federal Aviation Administration</a>, this airport had 4,415 passenger boardings (enplanements) in <a href="calendar%20year">calendar year</a> 2008, 3,560 in 2009, and 3,679 in 2010. The <a href="National%20Plan%20of%20Integrated%20Airport%20Systems">National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems</a> for 2011–2015 categorized it as a "<a href="FAA%20airport%20categories">non-primary commercial service</a>" airport.
Until 2018, the airport was subsidized by the <a href="Essential%20Air%20Service">Essential Air Service</a> to provide passenger air service. The EAS funding was terminated in January 2018, as not enough passengers were utilizing the airport.
Facilities and aircraft.
Chautauqua County/Jamestown Airport covers an area of 788 <a href="acre">acre</a>s (319 <a href="hectare">ha</a>) at an <a href="elevation">elevation</a> of 1,723 feet (525 m) above <a href="mean%20sea%20level">mean sea level</a>. It has two <a href="runway">runway</a>s with <a href="asphalt">asphalt</a> surfaces: 7/25 is 5,299 by 100 feet (1,615 x 30 m) and 13/31 is 4,500 by 100 feet (1,372 x 30 m).
For the 12-month period ending December 31, 2009, the airport had 16,394 aircraft operations, an average of 44 per day: 84% <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a>, 16% <a href="airline">scheduled commercial</a>, and <1% <a href="military%20aviation">military</a>. At that time there were 25 aircraft based at this airport: 76% single-<a href="aircraft%20engine">engine</a>, 20% multi-engine, and 4% <a href="helicopter">helicopter</a>.
Airlines and destinations.
After the suspension of the EAS funding, <a href="Southern%20Airways%20Express">Southern Airways Express</a>, the lone operator at the airport, withdrew its service, leaving the airport without any permanent airline tenants. <a href="Boutique%20Air">Boutique Air</a> has requested to restore service to the airport but is insisting on EAS funding to do so. The Federal Aviation Administration rejected any restoration of EAS funding to the airport in February 2019, reiterating its previous stance in withdrawing the funds.
Ground transportation.
The airport is served by <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%2060">New York State Route 60</a> and the <a href="Southern%20Tier%20Expressway">Southern Tier Expressway</a>.
Various taxis have access to and from the airport. <a href="The%20Hertz%20Corporation">The Hertz Corporation</a> has a car rental counter.
Shops and restaurants.
The airport currently has no permanent shops. The Tarmac Cafe, which previously provided meal services, closed in 2016.
